title.narrative: Research on retina and cognitive disorders in HIV-positive people

description.narrative: Despite the use of combination antiretroviral therapy (cART), cognitive impairment, classified as HIV Associated Neurocognitive Disorders (HAND), occurs in a substantial (15-60%) proportion of HIV patients. In addition to cognitive deficits, structural and functional abnormalities of the retina have been described in HIV-1-infected patients on cART without infectious retinitis. Thinning of the neuroretina has been demonstrated and corresponding subtle visual function loss develops, like loss of color vision and contrast sensitivity.

There are signs that people living with HIV are developing ageing-relating disorders at a younger age, such as forgetfulness or a retina condition. This research project aims to determine whether HIV-positive people with a retina disorder are at a higher risk of developing cognitive disorders and other brain conditions. If so, a simple eye examination can then be designed to conclude whether a person is in the risk group and requires extra monitoring.

This project aims to to assess the association between cognitive impairment and subtle brain and eye alterations in HIV-1-infected patients with sustained viral suppression on cART compared to HIV-negative controls of the same age. This study, baseline examination, follow-up examination after 2 years, and analysis of data of 125 subjects, can be performed in 3 years and will provide insight into the pathophysiology of neurocognitive disorders (HAND) in HIV positive patients by determining the value of a range of ophthalmologic, neuro-imaging and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) parameters to serve as biomarkers of cerebral dysfunction and predictors of cognitive and visual impairment in HIV-1-infected patients. This would help to identify people that might develop HAND.
This project is integrated in the COBRA study and the AGEhiv study
